column2: Though the small Swedish colony in Delaware was quickly submerged beneath the tide of English migration, the Dutch in New York continued to hold their own for more than a hundred years after the English conquest in 1664.
column3: Though the small Swedish colony in Delaware was quickly submerged beneath the tide of English migration, the Dutch in New York continued to hold their own for more than a hundred years after the English conquest in sixteen sixty four.

column2: At the end of the colonial period over one-half of the 170,000 inhabitants of the province were descendants of the original Dutch--still distinct enough to give a decided cast to the life and manners of New York.

column2: THE PROCESS OF COLONIZATION
column3: THE PROCESS OF COLONIZATION

column2: Considered from one side, colonization, whatever the motives of the emigrants, was an economic matter.
column3: Considered from one side, colonization, whatever the motives of the emigrants, was an economic matter.

column2: It involved the use of capital to pay for their passage, to sustain them on the voyage, and to start them on the way of production.
column3: It involved the use of capital to pay for their passage, to sustain them on the voyage, and to start them on the way of production.

column2: Under this stern economic necessity, Puritans, Scotch-Irish, Germans, and all were alike laid.
column3: Under this stern economic necessity, Puritans, Scotch Irish, Germans, and all were alike laid.

column2: =Immigrants Who Paid Their Own Way.=--Many of the immigrants to America in colonial days were capitalists themselves, in a small or a large way, and paid their own passage.
column3: equals Immigrants Who Paid Their Own Way.equals--Many of the immigrants to America in colonial days were capitalists themselves, in a small or a large way, and paid their own passage.

column2: What proportion of the colonists were able to finance their voyage across the sea is a matter of pure conjecture. Undoubtedly a very considerable number could do so, for we can trace the family fortunes of many early settlers.
column3: What proportion of the colonists were able to finance their voyage across the sea is a matter of pure conjecture. Undoubtedly a very considerable number could do so, for we can trace the family fortunes of many early settlers.

column2: Henry Cabot Lodge is authority for the statement that "the settlers of New England were drawn from the country gentlemen, small farmers, and yeomanry of the mother country....
column3: Henry Cabot Lodge is authority for the statement that "the settlers of New England were drawn from the country gentlemen, small farmers, and yeomanry of the mother country....

column2: Many of the emigrants were men of wealth, as the old lists show, and all of them, with few exceptions, were men of property and good standing.
column3: Many of the emigrants were men of wealth, as the old lists show, and all of them, with few exceptions, were men of property and good standing.

column2: They did not belong to the classes from which emigration is usually supplied, for they all had a stake in the country they left behind." Though it would be interesting to know how accurate this statement is or how applicable to the other colonies, no study has as yet been made to gratify that interest.

column2: For the present it is an unsolved problem just how many of the colonists were able to bear the cost of their own transfer to the New World.
column3: For the present it is an unsolved problem just how many of the colonists were able to bear the cost of their own transfer to the New World.

column2: =Indentured Servants.=--That at least tens of thousands of immigrants were unable to pay for their passage is established beyond the shadow of a doubt by the shipping records that have come down to us.

column2: The great barrier in the way of the poor who wanted to go to America was the cost of the sea voyage.
column3: The great barrier in the way of the poor who wanted to go to America was the cost of the sea voyage.

column2: To overcome this difficulty a plan was worked out whereby shipowners and other persons of means furnished the passage money to immigrants in return for their promise, or bond, to work for a term of years to repay the sum advanced.
column3: To overcome this difficulty a plan was worked out whereby shipowners and other persons of means furnished the passage money to immigrants in return for their promise, or bond, to work for a term of years to repay the sum advanced.

column2: This system was called indentured servitude.
column3: This system was called indentured servitude.

column2: It is probable that the number of bond servants exceeded the original twenty thousand Puritans, the yeomen, the Virginia gentlemen, and the Huguenots combined.
column3: It is probable that the number of bond servants exceeded the original twenty thousand Puritans, the yeomen, the Virginia gentlemen, and the Huguenots combined.

column2: All the way down the coast from Massachusetts to Georgia were to be found in the fields, kitchens, and workshops, men, women, and children serving out terms of bondage generally ranging from five to seven years.
column3: All the way down the coast from Massachusetts to Georgia were to be found in the fields, kitchens, and workshops, men, women, and children serving out terms of bondage generally ranging from five to seven years.

column2: In the proprietary colonies the proportion of bond servants was very high.

column2: The Baltimores, Penns, Carterets, and other promoters anxiously sought for workers of every nationality to till their fields, for land without labor was worth no more than land in the moon.
column3: The Baltimores, Penns, Carterets, and other promoters anxiously sought for workers of every nationality to till their fields, for land without labor was worth no more than land in the moon.

column2: Hence the gates of the proprietary colonies were flung wide open. Every inducement was offered to immigrants in the form of cheap land, and special efforts were made to increase the population by importing servants.

column2: In Pennsylvania, it was not uncommon to find a master with fifty bond servants on his estate.
column3: In Pennsylvania, it was not uncommon to find a master with fifty bond servants on his estate.

column2: It has been estimated that two-thirds of all the immigrants into Pennsylvania between the opening of the eighteenth century and the outbreak of the Revolution were in bondage. column2: The story of this traffic in white servants is one of the most striking things in the history of labor.

column2: Bondmen differed from the serfs of the feudal age in that they were not bound to the soil but to the master. They likewise differed from the negro slaves in that their servitude had a time limit.
column3: Bondmen differed from the serfs of the feudal age in that they were not bound to the soil but to the master. They likewise differed from the negro slaves in that their servitude had a time limit.

column2: Still they were subject to many special disabilities.

column2: It was, for instance, a common practice to impose on them penalties far heavier than were imposed upon freemen for the same offense.
column3: It was, for instance, a common practice to impose on them penalties far heavier than were imposed upon freemen for the same offense.

column2: A free citizen of Pennsylvania who indulged in horse racing and gambling was let off with a fine; a white servant guilty of the same unlawful conduct was whipped at the post and fined as well.
column3: A free citizen of Pennsylvania who indulged in horse racing and gambling was let off with a fine; a white servant guilty of the same unlawful conduct was whipped at the post and fined as well.

column2: The ordinary life of the white servant was also severely restricted.
column3: The ordinary life of the white servant was also severely restricted.

column2: A bondman could not marry without his master's consent; nor engage in trade; nor refuse work assigned to him.
column3: A bondman could not marry without his master's consent; nor engage in trade; nor refuse work assigned to him.

column2: For an attempt to escape or indeed for any infraction of the law, the term of service was extended. The condition of white bondmen in Virginia, according to Lodge, "was little better than that of slaves.
column3: For an attempt to escape or indeed for any infraction of the law, the term of service was extended. The condition of white bondmen in Virginia, according to Lodge, "was little better than that of slaves.

column2: Loose indentures and harsh laws put them at the mercy of their masters." It would not be unfair to add that such was their lot in all other colonies.

column2: Their fate depended upon the temper of their masters.

column2: Cruel as was the system in many ways, it gave thousands of people in the Old World a chance to reach the New--an opportunity to wrestle with fate for freedom and a home of their own.
column3: Cruel as was the system in many ways, it gave thousands of people in the Old World a chance to reach the New-an opportunity to wrestle with fate for freedom and a home of their own.

column2: For thousands, on the contrary, bondage proved to be a real avenue to freedom and prosperity.

column3: Some of the best citizens of America have the blood of indentured servants in their veins.

column2: =The Transported--Involuntary Servitude.=--In their anxiety to secure settlers, the companies and proprietors having colonies in America either resorted to or connived at the practice of kidnapping men, women, and children from the streets of English cities.
